title: HMAS Manoora (F48)
text:
HMAS "Manoora" was a passenger liner that served in the <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Navy">Royal Australian Navy</a> (RAN) during World War II. She was built in Scotland in 1935 for the <a href="Cairns%2C%20Queensland">Cairns</a> to <a href="Fremantle%2C%20Western%20Australia">Fremantle</a> coastal passenger run for the <a href="Adelaide%20Steamship%20Company">Adelaide Steamship Company</a>. She was requisitioned by the RAN for naval service in 1939. "Manoora" was initially converted into an <a href="armed%20merchant%20cruiser">armed merchant cruiser</a> (AMC), operating primarily in Australian, New Guinea, and Pacific waters, with deployments to Singapore and the Bay of Bengal.
In 1942, the ship was converted into the RAN's first <a href="landing%20ship%2C%20infantry">landing ship, infantry</a> (LSI). After extensive training, "Manoora" was involved in most of the Allied amphibious operations in the Pacific during 1944 and 1945. After the war's end, the ship was used to transport occupation forces and refugees until 1947, when she was decommissioned from naval service and returned to the Adelaide Steamship Company. "Manoora" continued to operate in Australian waters until 1961, when she was sold to an Indonesian company and renamed Albulombo. The ship was sold for scrap in 1972.
Design and construction.
The passenger liner was in <a href="length%20overall">length overall</a>, with a beam of , and a draught of . "Manoora" measured 10,900 <a href="gross%20register%20tonnage">gross register tons</a>. She had a twin-screw propulsion system, with diesel engines supplying to drive the ship at .
"Manoora" was built by <a href="Alexander%20Stephen%20and%20Sons">Alexander Stephen and Sons</a> in <a href="Govan">Govan</a>, Scotland for the <a href="Adelaide%20Steamship%20Company">Adelaide Steamship Company</a>. The ship was laid down in July 1934, launched on 25 October 1935, and completed in 1935.
It was a company policy for all its motor vessels to have a name starting with "M" and the liner was named after the town of <a href="Manoora%2C%20South%20Australia">Manoora</a> in <a href="South%20Australia">South Australia</a>. It was the sister ship of the <a href="Manunda">Mununda</a>.
The ship was launched by Lady Hore Ruthven (wife of the Governor of New South Wales).
Operational history.
"Manoora" entered service on the <a href="Cairns%2C%20Queensland">Cairns</a> to <a href="Fremantle%2C%20Western%20Australia">Fremantle</a> coastal passenger run.
Armed Merchant Cruiser.
On 14 November 1939, the liner was requisitioned by the RAN for use as an <a href="armed%20merchant%20cruiser">armed merchant cruiser</a> (AMC). The AMC conversion consisted of the addition of seven 6-inch main guns, two 3-inch anti-aircraft guns, and equipment to operate a <a href="Supermarine%20Walrus">Supermarine Walrus</a> amphibious aircraft. "Manoora" was commissioned into the RAN on 12 December 1939, although the conversion was not completed until 5 February 1940. She was assigned the <a href="pennant%20number">pennant number</a> F48.
Initially, the ship was used to patrol Australian waters, but during March 1940, she was redeployed to the <a href="China%20Station">China Station</a> to operate with the <a href="Malaya%20Force">Malaya Force</a>. During the ship's return to Australia in early April, "Manoora" intercepted four Norwegian merchant vessels and escorted them to Brisbane; Norway having recently fallen to the Germans, and the Allies wanted to ensure as many Norwegian-flagged vessel came under their control as possible. On 12 June, shortly after Italy became involved in the war, "Manoora" intercepted the Italian passenger vessel <a href="MV%20Romolo%20%281926%29">"Romolo"</a>, which was scuttled off the Solomon Islands. The AMC then provided assistance to United States cargo ship <a href="SS%20Admiral%20Wiley">"Admiral Wiley"</a>, which had run aground at <a href="Kitava">Kitava</a>.
Between the end of 1940 and September 1941, "Manoora"s operated around the north and east coasts of Australia, around New Guinea and New Britain, and to the Solomons, Nauru, and Ocean Island. In December, the AMC transported Admiral Sir <a href="Guy%20Royle">Guy Royle</a> to Singapore, then transited to the <a href="Bay%20of%20Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a> for escort duties. On 1 March 1942, the ship left Colombo for Australia, with a convoy of troopships returning from the Middle East.
Landing ship, infantry.
In mid-1942, "Manoora" was marked for conversion into the RAN's first <a href="landing%20ship%2C%20infantry">landing ship, infantry</a> (LSI) at <a href="Garden%20Island%20Dockyard">Garden Island Dockyard</a>. Her AMC armament was removed and replaced with a single 12-pounder gun, six <a href="40%20mm%20Bofors">40 mm Bofors</a>, and eight <a href="20%20mm%20Oerlikon">20 mm Oerlikon</a>s. The Walrus amphibian was removed, and the ship was modified to carry <a href="landing%20craft">landing craft</a>: 17 <a href="Landing%20Craft%2C%20Vehicle%2C%20Personnel">LCVPs</a>, and two <a href="Landing%20Craft%20Mechanized">LCMs</a>. "Manoora" was initially able to carry 850 soldiers, but later modifications increased this to 1,250. The ship was recommissioned on 2 February 1943 with the pennant number C77, and after spending six months on <a href="amphibious%20warfare">amphibious warfare</a> training in <a href="Port%20Phillip">Port Phillip</a>, was deployed to New Guinea.
After further training and exercises near <a href="Milne%20Bay">Milne Bay</a>, "Manoora" participated in her first amphibious landing on 22 April 1944; the <a href="Operation%20Reckless">Operation Reckless</a> landings at <a href="Tanamerah%20Bay">Tanamerah Bay</a>. Following Operation Reckless, the LSI saw service in most of the amphibious operations in the Pacific theatre. On 17 May, "Manoora" operated as part of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Wakde">Battle of Wakde</a>, followed by the landings at <a href="Battle%20of%20Morotai">Morotai</a> on 15 September, and <a href="Battle%20of%20Leyte">Leyte</a> during October. At the start of 1945, the ship participated in operations at <a href="Invasion%20of%20Lingayen%20Gulf">Lingayen Gulf</a>, followed by the <a href="Borneo%20campaign%20%281945%29">Borneo campaign</a>, with landings at <a href="Battle%20of%20Tarakan%20%281945%29">Tarakan</a> on 1 May, <a href="Battle%20of%20North%20Borneo">Brunei Bay</a> during 9 and 10 June, then <a href="Battle%20of%20Balikpapan%20%281945%29">Balikpapan</a> on 1 July. After this, "Manoora" sailed to Australia, and was in Sydney when World War II ended.
After the war's end, "Manoora" was used to transport the soldiers and equipment of occupation forces, and return evacuees from the East Indies region to their homes. The LSI's naval service ended on 6 December 1947, when she was decommissioned from naval service. She received six <a href="battle%20honour">battle honour</a>s for her wartime service: "Indian Ocean 1941–42", "Pacific 1942–45", "New Guinea 1944", "Leyte Gulf 1944", "Lingayen Gulf 1945", and "Borneo 1945".
Post-war career.
In 1947, Minister for Immigration <a href="Arthur%20Calwell">Arthur Calwell</a> requested the use of "Manoora" to help Australian and British citizens escape the increasing unrest in India <a href="Indian%20independence%20movement">preceding the nation's independence</a> and resettle them in Australia. Plans were made for multiple voyages from India to Australia, although only one sailing eventuated, arriving back in Fremantle on 15 August: austere accommodations on the barrack decks prompted many potential passengers to instead wait for commercial vessels. Although Calwell, a strong supporter of the <a href="White%20Australia%20Policy">White Australia Policy</a> insisted on passengers being "Australian/English by birth... of full European descent", most of the 736 passengers were <a href="Anglo-Indian">Anglo-Indian</a>s.
After two years of maintenance and refit at <a href="Cockatoo%20Island%20Dockyard">Cockatoo Island Dockyard</a> to remove the wartime modifications, "Manoora" was returned to the Adelaide Steamship Company on 31 August 1949.
In August 1969, the ship was sold to an Indonesian company, who renamed her "Albulombo". The ship was sold for scrap to a Japanese firm in October 1972, and <a href="ship%20breaking">broken up</a> in Taiwan.
Legacy.
The suburb of <a href="Manoora%2C%20Queensland">Manoora</a> in Cairns is named after the ship. The neighbouring suburb of <a href="Manunda%2C%20Queensland">Manunda</a> is named after the Manoora's sister ship <a href="Manunda">Manunda</a>.
